revision.text:
Public policy decisions are often decided by a group of individuals with different beliefs and interests.<ref>{{cite web|title=Characteristics of Successful Public Policy|url=http://publicadmin.norwich.edu/characteristics-of-successful-public-policy/|website=Norwich University|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref> The '''[[Public policy|policies]] of the [[United States of America]]''' comprise all actions taken by [[Federal government of the United States|its federal government]]. The [[Federal government of the United States#Executive branch|executive branch]] is the primary entity through which policies are enacted, however the policies are derived from a collection of laws, executive decisions, and [[legal precedent]]s. [[File:Uscapitolindaylight.jpg|right|thumb|250px|The [[United States Capitol]].]]
==Types of policies== {{main|List of public policy topics by country#United States}}
The policies of the United States The [[Almanac]] of Policy Issues, which provides background information, archived documents, and links to major U.S. public policy issues, organized the public policy of the United States into nine categories. The following lists these categories followed by a few examples of specific, respective policies:
*Criminal Justice: [[Capital punishment in the United States|death penalty]],<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/crime/archive/bjs_capital_punishment.shtml "Capital Punishment 2000"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 21, 2011.</ref> drug policy,<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/crime/archive/drug_abuse.shtml "Drug Abuse in America:2001"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 21, 2011.</ref> and gun control<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/crime/archive/crs_gun_control.shtml "Gun Control"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 21, 2011.</ref> *Culture and Society: [[abortion in the United States|abortion]],<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/culture/archive/crs_abortion_overview.shtml "Abortion Law Development: A Brief Overview"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514133610/http://www.policyalmanac.org/culture/archive/crs_abortion_overview.shtml |date=2011-05-14 }}, ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 21, 2011.</ref> arts,<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/culture/arts.shtml "Arts and humanities"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 21, 2011.</ref> and civil rights<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/culture/archive/discrimination.shtml "Federal Anti-Discrimination Laws"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 21, 2011.</ref> *Economic Affairs: budget and taxes<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/economic/budget.shtml "Budget and Taxes"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref> *Education: elementary and secondary,<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/education/archive/doe_state_of_education.shtml "The State of U.S. Education"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref> and [[Higher education in the United States|higher education]]<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/education/archive/2001_Postsecondary_Education.shtml "Post-Secondary Education Statistics"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref> *Environment: air quality<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/environment/archive/epa_clean_air_act.shtml "Plain English Guide To The Clean Air Act"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref> and global warming<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/environment/archive/climate_change.shtml "Climate Change"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref> *Government Operations: [[campaign finance reform]]<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/government/archive/2002-02-14_shays-meehan_summary.shtml "Summary of the Shay's-Meehan Campaign Finance Reform Law"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref> and privatization<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/government/charity_and_volunteerism.shtml "Charity and Volunteerism"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref> *Health: [[health insurance in the United States|health insurance]]<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/health/archive/health_insurance_coverage.shtml "Health Insurance Coverage"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref> and [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]]<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/health/archive/medicare_greenbook2000.shtml "2000 Ways and Means Green Book: Medicare"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref> *Social Welfare: social security<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/social_welfare/archive/crs_social_security_reform.shtml "Social Security Reform"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref> and welfare<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/social_welfare/archive/crs_welfare.shtml "Welfare Reform: An Issue Overview"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref> *Foreign Affairs and National Security: defense spending.<ref>Almanac of Policy Issues [http://www.policyalmanac.org/world/archive/FY_2004_Pentagon_Budget.shtml "FY 2004 Pentagon Budget"], ''Almanac of Policy Issues'', September 23, 2004, accessed March 30, 2011.</ref>
==Agricultural policy== [[Agricultural policy of the United States]] is the governing [[agricultural policy|policy]] for [[agriculture in the United States]] and is composed primarily of the periodically renewed federal [[U.S. farm bill]]s.
In "A New Agricultural Policy for the United States," authors Dennis Keeney and Long Kemp summarize the agricultural policy of the United States as follows: "Because of its unique geography, weather, history and policies, the United States has an agriculture that has been dominated by production of commodity crops for use in animal, industrial and export enterprises. Over time agricultural policies evolved to support an industrialized, commodity-based agriculture. This evolution resulted in farmers leaving the land with agriculture moving to an industrial structure."<ref>The Minnesota Project [http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:JjK5X-ACXlMJ:www.mnproject.org/pdf/A%2520New%2520Agriculture%2520Policy%2520for%2520the%2520U.S.%2520by%2520Dennis%2520Keeney%2520%2520Lo..pdf+a+new+agriculture+policy+united+states&hl=en&gl=us/''A New Agricultural Policy of the United States.''], July, 2003, accessed February 16, 2011.</ref> In parallel with the industrialization of agriculture in the United States, the Federal Government also developed the [[Dietary Guidelines for Americans]], which emphasize consumption of foods that are produced by large-scale farming.
==Drug policy==
The [[drug policy of the United States]] is established by The [[Office of National Drug Control Policy]], a former cabinet-level<ref name=csm>{{cite web | author = Cook, Dave | title = New drug czar gets lower rank, promise of higher visibility | publisher = ''Christian Science Monitor'' | date = 2009-03-11 | url = http://features.csmonitor.com/politics/2009/03/11/new-drug-czar-gets-lower-rank-promise-of-higher-visibility/ | accessdate = 2009-03-16 | quote = For one thing, in the Obama administration the Drug Czar will not have Cabinet status, as the job did during George W. Bush's administration. }}</ref> component of the [[Executive Office of the President of the United States]], which was established by the [[Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988]]. Its stated goal is to establish policies, priorities, and objectives to eradicate illicit [[Recreational drug use|drug use]], drug manufacturing, and [[drug trafficking|trafficking]], [[drug-related crime]] and violence, and drug-related health consequences in the U.S.
The Office of National Drug Control Policy's two current specific goals are to "curtail illicit drug consumption in America" and to "improve the public health and public safety of the American people by reducing the consequences of drug abuse."<ref name="whitehousedrugpolicy.gov">President Obama [http://www.whitehousedrugpolicy.gov/strategy/2010StrategyExecutiveSummary.pdf "2010 National Drug Control Policy."], ''Office of National Drug Control Policy'', 2010, accessed February 21, 2011.</ref> They plan to achieve these goals by taking the following actions:
*Strengthen efforts to prevent drug use in communities *Seek early intervention opportunities in health care *Integrate treatment for substance use disorders into health care, and expand support for recovery *Break the cycle of drug use, crime, delinquency, and incarceration *Disrupt domestic drug trafficking and production *Strengthen international partnerships *Improve information systems for analysis, assessment, and local management<ref name="whitehousedrugpolicy.gov"/>
==Energy policy== {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2011}} The [[energy policy of the United States]] addresses issues of energy production, distribution, and consumption, such as building codes and gas mileage standards. The [[United States Department of Energy]] plays a major role, and its mission is "to ensure America's security and prosperity by addressing its energy, environmental, and nuclear challenges through transformative science and technology solutions."
Moreover, the White House provides a summary of the United States' current condition regarding its energy policy: "For decades it has been clear that the way Americans produce and consume energy is not sustainable. Our addiction to foreign oil and fossil fuels puts our economy, our national security and our environment at risk. To take this country in a new direction, the President is working with Congress to pass comprehensive energy and climate legislation to protect our nation from the serious economic and strategic risks associated with our reliance on foreign oil, to create jobs, and to cut down on the carbon pollution that contributes to the destabilizing effects of climate change."
The following is a snapshot of the United States' current energy policy goals:
*Clean Energy Economy: make the investments in clean energy sources that will put Americans back in control of our energy future, create millions of new jobs and lay the foundation for long-term economic security. This will be accomplished by taking the following actions: **Initiating recovery act investments in clean energy **Applying more stringent appliance efficiency standards **Leading the way in sustainability **Creating efficiency standards for cars and trucks **Making homes more energy efficient
==Environmental policy== {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2011}} The [[environmental policy of the United States]] addresses and regulates activities that impact the environment. Its general goal is to protect the environment for the welfare of future generations. The environmental policy goals are detailed below:
*The Environment: the United States is committed to protecting our country's air, water, and land, from restoring ecosystems in the Chesapeake Bay and the Everglades, to reducing the impacts of mountaintop mining. Specifically, the environment will be protected by taking the following actions: **Protecting our oceans **Land conservation **Restoring our ecosystems **Renewing the federal commitment to California's Bay Delta **Chesapeake Bay protection and restoration **Great Lakes restoration **Limiting mercury emissions **Reducing the environmental impact of mountaintop coal mining **Reinvigorate the National Environmental Policy Act *Climate Change: the United States is committed to leading the charge to reduce the dangerous pollution that causes global warming, and to make the investments in the clean energy technology that will power sustainable growth in the future. The following are actions that will be taken to accomplish climate change goals: **Providing international leadership **Monitoring greenhouse gas emissions **Developing climate change adaptations<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Climate Change|url=https://www.state.gov/e/oes/climate/|website=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref> **Improving the educational curriculum for climate change science
==Foreign policy== {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2011}} The [[foreign policy of the United States]] defines how the United States interacts with foreign nations. It only addresses the security of the American people and promotes international order. The following are the most prominent foreign policies of the United States:
*Refocusing on the threat from al Qaeda in Afghanistan and Pakistan *Ending the war in Iraq responsibly *Keeping nuclear weapons out of the hands of terrorists *Promoting peace and security in Israel and the Middle East *Re-energizing America's alliances *Maintaining core American values *Restoring American leadership in Latin America *Ensuring energy security and fighting climate change
==Policy responses to the late-2000s recession== {{main|United States policy responses to the Great Recession}} The Federal Reserve, Treasury, and Securities and Exchange Commission took several steps on September 19 to intervene in the crisis. To stop the potential run on money market mutual funds, the Treasury also announced on September 19 a new $50 billion program to insure the investments, similar to the [[Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation]] (FDIC) program.<ref>Gullapalli, Diya and Anand, Shefali. [http://wsj.com/article/SB122186683086958875.html?mod=article-outset-box "Bailout of Money Funds Seems to Stanch Outflow"], [[The Wall Street Journal]], September 20, 2008.</ref> Part of the announcements included temporary exceptions to section 23A and 23B (Regulation W), allowing financial groups to more easily share funds within their group. The exceptions would expire on January 30, 2009, unless extended by the [[Federal Reserve Board]].<ref>[http://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/press/monetary/20080919c.htm (Press Release) FRB: Board Approves Two Interim Final Rules], [[Federal Reserve Bank]], September 19, 2008.</ref> The Securities and Exchange Commission announced termination of short-selling of 799 financial stocks, as well as action against [[naked short selling]], as part of its reaction to the mortgage crisis.<ref>Boak, Joshua (''[[Chicago Tribune]]''). [http://www.mercurynews.com/markets/ci_10513612 "SEC temporarily suspends short selling"], [[San Jose Mercury News]], September 19, 2008.</ref>

{{COI|date=January 2012}} '''Policy alienation''' refers to a framework which examines the experiences of governmental employees with new policies they have to implement. It has been used to describe the experiences of front-line public professionals with new policies. It is defined "as a general cognitive state of psychological disconnection from the policy programme being implemented."
==Introduction== A number of examples can clarify the concept of policy alienation. For example, Bottery (1998:40),<ref>{{cite book|last=Bottery|first=M.|title=Professionals and policy: Management strategy in a competitive world|year=1998|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0-304-70157-5}}</ref> examining the pressures on professionals stemming from new policies in education and [[health care]] in Great Britain, cites a teacher arguing that: “The changes have been outrageous, and have produced a culture of meritocracy and high flyers. There’s massive paperwork because the politicians don’t believe teachers are to be trusted.” This indicates that professionals had difficulties identifying with the policies they had to implement. A second example refers to the introduction of a new reimbursement policy in mental healthcare in the Netherlands. In one large-scale survey, as many as nine out of ten professionals wanted to abandon this new policy (Palm et al., 2008).<ref>{{cite book|last=Palm, I., Leffers, F., Emons, T., Van Egmond, V., & Zeegers, S.|title=De GGz ontwricht: Een praktijkonderzoek naar de gevolgen van het nieuwe zorgstelsel in de geestelijke gezondheidszorg|year=2008|publisher=SP|location=The Hague|url=http://www.sp.nl/service/rapport/081025GGZ_ontwricht.pdf}}</ref> Psychologists even went as far as to openly demonstrate on the street against this policy. A major reason for this was that many could not align their professional values with the content of the policy. As one professional noted:
''"Within the new healthcare system economic values are dominant. Too little attention is being paid to the content: professionals helping patients. The result is that professionals become more aware of the costs and revenues of their behavior. This comes at the expense of acting according to professional standards.”''{{Attribution needed|date=June 2012}}
Overall, a number of studies show an increasing discontent among public professionals toward public policies (see also Hebson et al., 2003; White, 1996),<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hebson, G., Grimshaw, D., & Marchington, M.|title=PPPs and the changing public sector ethos: Case-study evidence from the health and local authority sectors|journal=Work Employment and Society|year=2003|volume=17|issue=3|pages=481–501|doi=10.1177/09500170030173005|url=http://wes.sagepub.com/content/17/3/481.short|accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=White, D.|title=A balancing act: Mental health policy-making in Quebec|journal=International Journal of Law and Psychiatry|year=1996|volume=19|issue=4|pages=289–307|pmid=8968814|doi=10.1016/s0160-2527(96)80005-7}}</ref> although more positive experiences can also be found (Ruiter, 2007).<ref>{{cite book|last=Ruiter, A. E. P.|title=Implementatie van het structureel echoscopisch onderzoek: Samenwerking en kwaliteitsdenken|year=2007|publisher=University of Twente|location=Twemte|url=http://essay.utwente.nl/58027/}}</ref> The policy alienation framework was developed to better understand the experiences of front-line public professionals with new policies.
==Effects of policy alienation== Currently, there is an intense debate concerning professionals in the public sector. Many of the pressures that professionals face are related to the difficulties they have with the policies they have to implement.<ref>{{cite book|editors=Duyvendak, W. G. J., Knijn, T., & Kremer, M.|title=Policy, people, and the new professional. de-professionalisation and re-professionalisation in care and welfare|year=2006|publisher=[[Amsterdam University Press]]|location=Amsterdam|isbn=978-90-5356-885-9}}</ref> When implementers are unable to identify with a policy, this can negatively influence policy effectiveness. Furthermore, a high degree of policy alienation can affect the quality of interactions between professionals and citizens, which may eventually influence the output legitimacy of government.<ref>{{cite book|authors=Bekkers, V. J. J. M., Edwards, A., Fenger, M., & Dijkstra, G.|title=Governance and the Democratic Deficit, assessing the legitimacy of governance practices|year=2007|publisher=Aldershot|location=Ashgate|isbn=978-0-7546-4983-0}}</ref> The policy alienation framework is used to analyze this topic.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tummers|first=L.G. |author2=Bekkers, V.J.J.M. |author3=Steijn, A.J.|title=Policy alienation of public professionals: Application in a new public management context|journal=Public Management Review|year=2009|volume=11|issue=5|pages=685–706|doi=10.1080/14719030902798230|url=http://repub.eur.nl/pub/16897 }}</ref> It has been shown that policy alienation increases resistance to a new policy, lowers behavioral support for the policy and decreases job satisfaction of public professionals.<ref>{{cite book|last=Tummers, L.G.|title=Policy alienation - Analyzing the experiences of public professionals with new policies|year=2012|publisher=Erasmus University Rotterdam|location=Rotterdam}}</ref> Hence, it has both influences on the individual professional, as well as on policy effectiveness.
== Conceptualization == Alienation broadly refers to a sense of social estrangement, an absence of social support or meaningful social connection. Sociologists, [[public administration]] scholars, and other social scientists have used the alienation concept in various studies. As a result, a number of meanings have been attributed to the term.<ref name=Kanungo>{{cite book|last=Kanungo|first=R.|title=Work alienation: an integrative approach|year=1982|publisher=Praeger Publishers|location=New York|isbn=978-0-03-060241-2}}</ref> In an attempt to provide clarity, Seeman broke these meanings down into [[Social alienation|five alienation dimensions]]: powerlessness, meaninglessness, normlessness, social isolation, and self-estrangement.
Many scholars have used these dimensions to devise operational measures for alienation so that they can examine the concept in a range of settings. Mau, for example, used four dimensions in examining student alienation. Rayce et al., when investigating adolescent alienation, used three of the five dimensions. Further, many other researchers have used Seeman’s classification in examining the concept of work alienation. [[Bob Blauner|Blauner]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Blauner, R.|title=Alienation and freedom|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago}}</ref> devised operational measures for three of the dimensions: powerlessness, meaninglessness, and social isolation.
The policy alienation framework was conceptualized based on the works of sociologists such as [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|Hegel]], [[Karl Marx|Marx]], Seeman, and Blauner. Furthermore, works of public administration scholars were used, particularly on [[Michael Lipsky|Lipsky]] (street-level bureaucracy). Like work alienation, policy alienation is multidimensional, consisting of policy powerlessness and policy meaninglessness dimensions. In the work alienation literature, the dimensions of powerlessness and meaninglessness are also considered very important.<ref name=Kanungo />
In essence, powerlessness is a person's lack of control over events in their life. In the realm of policy formulation and implementation, policy powerlessness relates to the degree of influence public professionals have over shaping a policy program. Powerlessness can occur when a new policy is drafted without the help of the professionals, by for example not consulting their professionals associations or labor unions. Furthermore, on an operational level professionals can feel powerless when they have to adhere to tight procedures and rules when implementing a policy (see also [[Michael Lipsky|Lipsky]]). This kind of powerlessness may be particularly pronounced in professionals whose expectations of discretion and autonomy contradict notions of bureaucratic control (see also [[Profession]]).<ref>{{cite book|last=Freidson, E.|title=Professionalism: The third logic|year=2001|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=978-0-226-26203-1}}</ref>
The second dimension of policy alienation is meaninglessness. In the realm of policy making and implementation, policy meaninglessness refers to a professional’s perception of the contribution that the policy makes to a greater purpose, most notably to society or to their own clients. For instance, a professional can feel that implementing a policy is meaningless, if it does not deliver any apparent beneficial outcomes for society, such as more safety on the streets.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Van Thiel, S., & Leeuw, F. L.|title=The performance paradox in the public sector|journal=Public Performance and Management Review|year=2002|volume=25|issue=3|pages=267–281|doi=10.2307/3381236|url=http://repub.eur.nl/res/pub/1577/BSK074.pdf|jstor=3381236|hdl=1765/1577}}</ref>
To make the dimensions more specific, five sub-dimensions were identified: strategic, tactical and operational powerlessness, societal and client meaninglessness. This is shown in the table below.
'''Five sub-dimensions of policy alienation''' {| class="wikitable" |- ! Sub-dimension !! Definition !! Example of high scores |- | Strategic powerlessness || The perceived influence of the professionals on decisions concerning the content of the policy, as is captured in rules and regulations || A professional feeling that the policy is drafted without the help of implementing professionals or professional associations. |- | Tactical powerlessness || The professionals’ perceived influence on decisions concerning the way policy is implemented within their own organization. || Professionals stating that the managers in the organization did not consult them or their colleagues when designing the implementation process for the policy. |- | Operational powerlessness || The perceived degree of freedom in making choices concerning the sort, quantity and quality of sanctions and rewards on offer when implementing the policy. || Answering ‘fully agree’ to a survey question on whether the professional feels that their autonomy during the implementation process was lower than it should be. |- | Societal meaninglessness || The perception of professionals concerning the added value of the policy to socially relevant goals. || Stating in an interview that “I agree with the policy goal of enhancing transparency, but I do not see how this policy helps in achieving this goal.” |- | Client meaninglessness || The professionals’ perceptions of the added value of their implementing a policy for their own clients. || A professional who argues that a particular policy seriously impinges on their clients’ privacy. |}
==See also== *[[Anomie]] *[[Marx's theory of alienation]] *[[Political alienation]] *[[Social comparison theory]] *[[Public management]]

'''Nosokinetics''' is the science/subject of measuring and modelling the process of care in [[health care|health]] and [[social care]] systems.<ref name=nosok>[http://info200.infc.ulst.ac.uk/nosokinetics/ Nosokinetics website]</ref>'' Nosokinetics'' brings together the [[Greek language|Greek]] words for ''noso'': disease and ''kinetics'': movement.
[[Black box]] models are currently used to plan changes in health and social care systems. These input-output models overlook the process of inpatient care, as a result suboptimal decisions are made. Nosokinetics, (analogous to [[Pharmacokinetics]]), seeks to develop dynamic methods which measure and model the process of inpatient care. The aim is to develop a scientific base to underpin the planning of sustainable health and social care systems. == Establishment == Nosokinetics is a new ''science'' that was established in the UK in the early 1990s by Prof [[Peter H Millard]] after publishing his PhD thesis. In 2004 Nosokinetics group newsletter was established.<ref>[http://info200.infc.ulst.ac.uk/events/hscm2008/keynotes.html Peter Millard Resume & Photo] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100825172724/http://info200.infc.ulst.ac.uk/events/hscm2008/keynotes.html |date=August 25, 2010 }}</ref>
== Origin == Prof [[Peter H Millard]] writes about Nosokinetics : "If the random forces of wind and tide can make such a beautiful statue (referring to an [[iceberg]]), how much better could [[human|mankind]] do if a new [[science]] was developed which explains the complex processes of health and social care. Until new methods of planning health and social care services to meet the needs of an [[ageing]] population are introduced, service delivery will stumble on from [[crisis]] to crisis. The world population is ageing and sustainable systems of health care need to be developed."<ref name=nosok/>
He has established the nosokinetics group of interested [[researcher]]s. The group collaborates to organize [[Academic conference|conferences]] and disseminates [[news]] of nosokinetics and other researchers' research and practical use of modelling to enhance decision making in health and social care systems.<ref name=nosok/>
== Network == The Nosokinetics Group has succeeded in attracting a lot of researchers. Nosokinetics interested people are present in many countries including [[Australia]], [[UK]] & [[Egypt]]. They are from different disciplines ranging from health care providers to management scientists. The news related to nosokinetics is shared to the network through the bimonthly newsletter ''Nosokinetics News''<ref>[http://info200.infc.ulst.ac.uk/nosokinetics/newsletter.htm Nosokinetics newsletter archive]</ref> which helps to communicate papers, conferences and events of interest to the Nosokinetics network. == See also == *[[Health administration]] *[[Association of University Programs in Health Administration]]

'''Policy studies''' is a subdisicipline of [[political science]] that includes the analysis of the process of policymaking (the policy process) and the contents of policy ([[policy analysis]]).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ascher|first1=William|title=The evolution of the policy sciences: Understanding the rise and avoiding the fall|journal=Journal of Policy Analysis and Management|volume=5|issue=2|pages=365–373|date=1986|doi=10.2307/3323551|jstor=3323551}}</ref> Policy analysis includes substantive area research (such as health or education policy), [[program evaluation]] and impact studies, and policy design.<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=419922|title=Political Science and Public Policy|first1=Paul|last1=Sabatier|date=1 June 1991|journal=Political Science & Politics|volume=24|issue=2|pages=144–147|doi=10.2307/419922}}</ref> It "involves systematically studying the nature, causes, and effects of alternative [[public policies]], with particular emphasis on determining the [[policies]] that will achieve given goals."<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=3110267|title=The Policy Studies Perspective|first1=Stuart S.|last1=Nagel|first2=Duncan|last2=MacRae|editor-first1=Robert L.|editor-last1=Lineberry|editor-first2=Theodore J.|editor-last2=Lowi|editor-first3=Alan|editor-last3=Stone|editor-first4=Charles O.|editor-last4=Jones|editor-first5=James A.|editor-last5=Wilde|editor-first6=R. A. W.|editor-last6=Rhodes|date=1 January 1980|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=40|issue=4|pages=391–396|doi=10.2307/3110267}}</ref> It emerged in the United States in the 1960s and 1970s.
Policy Studies also examines the conflicts and conflict resolution that arise from the making of policies in civil society, the private sector, or more commonly, in the public sector (e.g. government).
It frequently focuses on the [[public sector]] but is equally applicable to other kinds of organizations (e.g., the not-for-profit sector). Some policy study experts graduate from [[public policy school]]s with [[public policy degrees]]. Alternatively, experts may have backgrounds in [[policy analysis]], [[program evaluation]], [[sociology]], [[psychology]], [[philosophy]], [[economics]], [[anthropology]], [[geography]], [[law]], [[political science]], [[social work]], [[environmental planning]] and [[public administration]].
Traditionally, the field of policy studies focused on [[domestic policy]], with the notable exceptions of [[foreign policy|foreign]] and [[defense policy|defense policies]]. However, the wave of [[economic globalization]], which ensued in the late 20th and early 21st centuries, created a need for a subset of policy studies that focuses on [[global governance]], especially as it relates to issues that transcend [[national borders]] such as [[climate change]], [[terrorism]], [[nuclear proliferation]], and [[economic development]]. This subset of policy studies, which is often referred to as international policy studies, typically requires mastery of a [[second language]] and attention to [[cross-cultural]] issues in order to address [[nation]]al and [[cultural bias]]es. For example, the [[Monterey Institute of International Studies]] at [[Middlebury College]] offers Master of Arts programs that focus exclusively on international policy through a mix of [[interdisciplinary]] and [[cross-cultural]] analysis called the "Monterey Way".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.miis.edu/academics/courses|title=Courses - Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey|publisher=}}</ref> Examples of academic programs in policy studies include the [[Harvard Kennedy School]] and the [[LBJ School of Public Affairs]].

'''Blanket policy''' is a [[policy]] which behaves similarly to a variety of things. Based on [[Webster's Dictionary]] it "covers a group or class of things or properties instead of one or more things mentioned individually, as where a [[Mortgage law|mortgage]] secures various [[debt]]s as a group, or subjects a group or class of different pieces of property to one general lien."

{{distinguish|Open-access policy}} '''Open educational resource policies (OER policies)''' are principles or tenets adopted by governing bodies in support of the use of [[open content]]—specifically [[open educational resources]] (OER) -- and [[Open Educational Practices|practices]] in educational institutions. Such policies are emerging increasingly at the national, state/province, and local levels.<ref>{{cite book|title=Giving Knowledge for Free: The Emergence of Open Educational Resources|year=2007|publisher=Centre for Educational Research and Innovation (CERI), OECD|url=http://www.oecd.org/edu/ceri/38654317.pdf|accessdate=24 April 2013}}</ref> [[Creative Commons]] defines (OER) policies as "legislation, institutional policies, and/or funder mandates that lead to the creation, increased use, and/or support for improving OER."<ref>{{cite web|title=OER Policy Registry|url=http://wiki.creativecommons.org/OER_Policy_Registry|publisher=Creative Commons|accessdate=24 April 2013}}</ref> OER are learning materials that reside in the public domain or have been released under an [[free license|intellectual property license]] that permits their free use and re-purposing by others.<ref>{{cite web|title=Open Educational Resources|url=http://www.hewlett.org/programs/education-program/open-educational-resources|publisher=William and Flora Hewlett Foundation|accessdate=24 April 2013}}</ref>
== OER Policy Clearinghouses == [[Creative Commons]] hosts an open educational resources policy registry which lists 112 current and proposed open education policies from around the world.<ref>{{cite web|title=OER Policy Registry|url=http://wiki.creativecommons.org/OER_Policy_Registry|publisher=Creative Commons|accessdate=14 April 2014}}</ref>
Another resource for finding OER policies is the Open Educational Quality Initiative [http://www.oer-quality.org/clearinghouse/browse/ OPAL Best Practice Clearing House]. The OPAL Initiative is a partnership between seven organizations including the [http://www.icde.org International Council for Open and Distance Education] (ICDE), UNESCO, European Foundation for Quality, the Open University UK, Aalto University and the Catholic University Portugal. Led by the University of Duisburg-Essen in Germany, it is partly funded by the European Commission.<ref>{{cite web | title = The OPAL Initiative | url = http://www.oer-quality.org/the-opal-initiative/ | website = OPAL Open Educational Quality Initiative | publisher = University Duisburg Essen | accessdate = 23 March 2013}}</ref>
== UNESCO OER Congress == On Friday 22 June 2012, the [[UNESCO]] World Open Educational Resources (OER) Congress released the [[UNESCO 2012 Paris OER Declaration|2012 Paris OER Declaration]]<ref>{{cite news|title=2012 Paris OER Declaration|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/fileadmin/MULTIMEDIA/HQ/CI/CI/pdf/Events/Paris%20OER%20Declaration_01.pdf|newspaper=2012 World Open Educational Resources (OER) Congress UNESCO, Paris, June 20–22, 2012}}</ref> which called on governments to openly license publicly funded educational materials.<ref>{{cite web|title=UNESCO World OER Congress releases 2012 Paris OER Declaration|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/resources/news-and-in-focus-articles/all-news/news/unesco_world_oer_congress_releases_2012_paris_oer_declaration/|accessdate=24 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Open Educational Resources Congress passes historic declaration|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/resources/news-and-in-focus-articles/in-focus-articles/2012/open-educational-resources-congress-passes-historic-declaration/|accessdate=24 April 2013}}</ref>
UNESCO member states unanimously approved the declaration,<ref>{{cite news|last=Green|first=Cable|title=2012 Paris OER Declaration|url=https://creativecommons.org/weblog/entry/33089|newspaper=Creative Commons blog|date=29 June 2013}}</ref> which highlights the importance of [[open educational resources]] and gives recommendations to governments and institutions around the globe.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Pawlowski|first=J.M.|author2=Hoel, T.|title=Towards a Global Policy for Open Educational Resources: The Paris OER Declaration and its Implications|journal=White Paper 0.2|year=2012|url=http://monet.informatik.rwth-aachen.de/giotto/OpenScout_df6f1252-bfa6-11e1-a668-e13baff9bd23.pdf}}</ref>
== Policies adopted by national councils of education == On January 17, 2014, the Council on Higher Education in South Africa published a ''[http://www.che.ac.za/announcements/white-paper-post-school-education-and-training White Paper for Post-School Education and Training]''. This paper emphasized open learning principles and set the stage for supporting national efforts to design and develop high-quality open educational resources. In response the [http://oeru.org/oeru-partners/university-of-south-africa/ University of South Africa (UNISA)]—one of the founding partners of the [http://wikieducator.org/OERu/Home OERu network] and a member of the 2012 Unesco OER conference in Paris—approved an Open Educational Resource (OER) Strategy in March 2014.<ref>{{cite web | title = Open Education Resources (OER) Strategy, 2014-2016 | publisher = University of South Africa (UNISA) | url = http://www.unisa.ac.za/contents/unisaopen/docs/OER%20Strategy%20%28final%29%20March%202014.pdf | date = 26 March 2014 | accessdate = 20 May 2014}}</ref>
== Policies adopted by research universities == An open-access policy enacted by the Faculty of a research university can empower them in choosing how to distribute their own scholarly work. If a faculty member wishes to grant exclusive rights to a publisher, they would first need to request a waiver from their faculty governance body. Some reasons to implement this kind of policy institution-wide are to: # increase the overall impact of an institution's research contributions to the global knowledge economy, # individual faculty receive their institution's full support in a unified action to work with publishers to simplify procedures and broaden access to their scholarly work (allowing for greater possibilities for citations of their work - important for hiring, tenure and promotion decisions), # take advantage of scholarly interactions with a greater diversity of readers, not just those who can afford to purchase the information from a vendor or attend an academic conference.
This kind of blanket policy provides support to those whose research is not part of a project that requires open access to the research done. For example, since the [https://web.archive.org/web/20160310081557/https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/microsites/ostp/ostp_public_access_memo_2013.pdf February 2013 directive] from the [http://www.whitehouse.gov/administration/eop/ostp United States Office of Science and Technology Policy], U.S. federal agencies have been developing their own policies on making research freely available within a year of publication.
SPARC, the [http://sparc.arl.org/about Scholarly Publishing and Academic Resources Coalition], led the collaborative and open effort to create an "Open Access Spectrum" that demonstrates a more sophisticated approach is needed in discussions about the concept of openness in research communications. The [http://sparc.arl.org/resource/howopenisit "HowOpenIsIt? Guide] (as well as an FAQ document and slide deck) is available for download on the SPARC website.<ref>{{cite web | last = Yaplee | first = Darlene | title = HowOpenIsIt? New Guide Released | website = Scholarly Publishing and Academic Resources Coalition (SPARC) | publisher = Association of Research Libraries | url = http://sparc.arl.org/resource/howopenisit | place = Washington D.C. | accessdate = April 17, 2014}}</ref> Another useful guide has been developed by members of the Harvard Office for Scholarly Communication, the Harvard Open Access Project, and the Berkman Center for Internet and Society. This online guide, "[https://cyber.law.harvard.edu/hoap/Good_practices_for_university_open-access_policies Good practices for university open-access policies]" is built on a wiki and is designed to evolve over time, according to the co-authors: Emily Kilcer, Stuart Shieber and Peter Suber.<ref>{{cite web | title = Good practices for university open-access policies | website = Harvard Open Access Project | publisher = Berkman Center for Internet and Society, Harvard University | place = Cambridge, MA | url = https://cyber.law.harvard.edu/hoap/Good_practices_for_university_open-access_policies | accessdate = April 17, 2014}}</ref>
===United States=== ==== California Institute of Technology ==== On June 10, 2013, the Faculty Board of the [[California Institute of Technology]] (Caltech) created an institution-wide Open Access Policy.<ref>{{cite news | last = Schaffhauser | first = Dian | title = Caltech Adopts Open Access Policy for Scholarly Writing | date = 6 January 2014 | url = http://campustechnology.com/articles/2014/01/06/caltech-adopts-open-access-policy-for-scholarly-writing.aspx | newspaper= Campus Technology |location= Chatsworth, CA |publisher= 1105 Media Inc, Ed-Tech Group | accessdate = 2 April 2014}}</ref> The ruling<ref>{{cite web | title = California Institute of Technology Open Access Policy, Approved by the Caltech Faculty Board on June 10, 2013 | url = http://library.caltech.edu/coda/OA_Policy_6.10.2013.pdf | last = Faculty Board | first = California Institute of Technology | accessdate = 2 April 2014}}</ref> stated that as of January 1, 2014, all Caltech faculty must agree to grant nonexclusive rights to Caltech to disseminate their scholarly papers either via the authors' own sites or to Caltech AUTHORS, the online repository. The goal is to encourage wider distribution of their work and to simplify the copyright process when posting research on faculty or institutional Web sites. The initiative was put in place to prevent publishers of those journals from threatening legal action or issuing takedown notices to authors who have posted their content on their own sites or to [http://authors.library.caltech.edu/ CaltechAUTHORS], an online repository for research papers authored by Caltech faculty and other researchers at Caltech.
==== Duke University ==== On March 21, 2010,<ref>{{cite web | first = Geoffrey | last = Mock | title = Faculty Move Forward on Open Access Policy | website = DukeToday | publisher = Office of News and Communications, Duke University | date = 21 March 2010 | url = http://today.duke.edu/2010/03/accessvote.html }}</ref> the [[Duke University]] Academic Council voted to support the University Library's new data repository, [http://dukespace.lib.duke.edu/dspace/ DukeSpace], with a blanket policy to provide open access to their scholarly writings. The policy allows for faculty members to opt out at any time, and it is regularly reviewed to determine its effectiveness.
Duke also in 2010 joined the [http://www.oacompact.org/ Compact for Open-Access Publishing Equity] (COPE) and established a fund to help Duke faculty members to cover any [[author fees]] required to publish in open access journals.<ref>{{cite web | title = Open Access at Duke University | website = Duke University Libraries | url = http://library.duke.edu/research/openaccess | publisher = Duke University | accessdate = 3 April 2014}}</ref>
==== Harvard University ==== On February 12, 2008, the Faculty of Arts and Sciences of [[Harvard University]] approved their [https://osc.hul.harvard.edu/hfaspolicy Open Access Policy], granting to the President and Fellows of Harvard to "make available his or her scholarly articles and to exercise the copyright in those articles ... in a nonexclusive, irrevocable, paid-up, worldwide license..."<ref>{{cite web | title = Harvard Faculty of Arts and Sciences Open Access Policy, Voted February 12, 2008 | website = Office for Scholarly Communication | publisher = Harvard University Library | location = Cambridge, MA | url = https://osc.hul.harvard.edu/hfaspolicy | accessdate = 3 April 2014}}</ref> Since then, several other schools within the University now participate in the Open Access Policies supported by the Office for Scholarly Communication: the Graduate School of Design, the School of Education, the Business School, the Law School, the Kennedy School of Government, the Divinity School, and the School of Public Health.<ref>{{cite web | title = Open Access Policies | website = Office for Scholarly Communication | publisher = Harvard University Library | location = Cambridge, MA | url = https://osc.hul.harvard.edu/policies}}</ref> The University's open-access repository is called [https://osc.hul.harvard.edu/dash/ DASH] (Digital Access to Scholarship at Harvard) which is where the faculty upload their scholarly articles for access by all.
==== Massachusetts Institute of Technology ==== Adopted by a unanimous vote on March 18, 2009, the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT) Faculty adopted an open access policy. The policy applies to "all scholarly articles written while the person is a member of the Faculty except for any articles completed before the adoption of this policy and any articles for which the Faculty member entered into an incompatible licensing or assignment agreement before the adoption of this policy."<ref>{{cite web | title = MIT Faculty Open Access Policy | website = Scholarly Publishing @ MIT | publisher = Massachusetts Institute of Technology | url = http://libraries.mit.edu/scholarly/mit-open-access/open-access-at-mit/mit-open-access-policy/ | accessdate = April 3, 2014}}</ref> The MIT online repository is called [http://dspace.mit.edu/login DSpace@MIT] and it was designed to work seamlessly with Google Scholar. The Faculty revised and updated the policy in 2010 to take into consideration the various issues associated with the MIT librarians' discussions with publishers.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Holton|first=Richard|title=Maintaining Our Resolutions: Implementing the MIT Faculty Open Access Policy|journal=MIT Faculty Newsletter|date=November–December 2010|volume=XXIII|issue=2|url=http://web.mit.edu/fnl/volume/232/holton.html|accessdate=April 3, 2014}}</ref>
==== Princeton University ==== In 2010 the Dean of the Faculty of [[Princeton University]] appointed an ad-hoc committee of faculty and the University Librarian to study the question of open access to faculty publications - and in March 2011, the committee recommended several changes to the Faculty rules to allow for a blanket policy for open access to Princeton faculty scholarship.<ref>{{cite web | title = Memo to the Faculty Advisory Committee on Policy from the Ad-hoc Faculty Committee to study Open Access | url = http://www.princeton.edu/dof/policies/publ/fac/open-access-policy/open-access-report.pdf | website = Office of the Dean of the Faculty | publisher = Princeton University | accessdate = 3 April 2014}}</ref> The faculty approved an open access policy on September 19, 2011, which was last revised in January 2012.<ref>{{cite web | title = Open Access Policy | website = Office of the Dean of the Faculty | publisher = Princeton University | url = http://www.princeton.edu/dof/policies/publ/fac/open-access-policy/ | accessdate = 3 April 2014}}</ref>
==== Stanford University ==== On June 26, 2008, the [[Stanford University]] Graduate School of Education (GSE) were the first in that school to grant permission to the University to make their scholarly articles publicly accessible and to exercise the copyright in a "nonexclusive, irrevocable, worldwide license ... provided that the articles are properly attributed to the authors not sold for a profit."<ref>{{cite web | title = GSE Open Access Motion | website = Stanford Graduate School of Education | publisher = Stanford University | url = https://ed.stanford.edu/faculty-research/open-archive/open-access-motion | accessdate = 3 April 2014}}</ref> The [https://openarchive.stanford.edu/ GSE Open Archive] houses and makes publicly available the GSE authors' working papers as well as published articles. Between May 21-24th, 2013, the Stanford GSE doctoral students voted in favor of a motion to enact an Open Access policy.<ref>{{cite web | title = GSE Student Open Archive Motion | website = Stanford Graduate School of Education | publisher = Stanford University | url = https://openarchive.stanford.edu/content/gse-student-open-archive-motion | accessdate = 3 April 2014}}</ref> At this time, however, despite the strong case made by Professors John Willinsky and Juan Pablo Alperin,<ref>{{cite web | first = John | last = Willinsky | first2 = Juan Pablo | last2 = Alperin | title = The academic ethics of open access to research and scholarship | website = Open Archive | publisher = Stanford University | url = https://openarchive.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/Wilinsky_Alperin_0.pdf | year = 2011 | accessdate = 3 April 2014}}</ref> no other Stanford academic units have stepped forward.
==== University of California ==== On July 24, 2013, the Academic Senate of the [[University of California]] (UC) approved the UC Open Access Policy for all 8,000 plus faculty at their ten campuses.<ref>{{cite web | title = UC Open Access Policy | website = Office of Scholarly Communication | publisher = University of California | url = http://osc.universityofcalifornia.edu/open-access-policy/ | accessdate = 3 April 2014}}</ref> Some confusion at the local campuses led to online postings of journal articles whose copyright was already owned by publishers. For example, in December 2013, the academic publishing company [http://www.elsevier.com Elsevier] sent several UC faculty notices to take down certain journal articles posted openly on their campus webpages, e.g., on the department websites or faculty profiles.<ref>{{cite web | title = Elsevier Takedown Notices for Faculty Articles on UC Sites | website = Office of Scholarly Communication | publisher = University of California | url = http://osc.universityofcalifornia.edu/2013/12/elsevier-takedown-notices/ | accessdate = 3 April 2014}}</ref> The UC Open Access Policy protected those faculty who had correctly uploaded their articles to the UC [http://osc.universityofcalifornia.edu/publishing-tools/ eScholarship] repository. In another case of misunderstanding by the faculty about open access, in March 2014 the University received a [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA) takedown notice for nine articles owned by the American Society for Civil Engineers (ASCE). The UC faculty authors had uploaded to eScholarship the publisher-formatted articles between 2004 and 2008, before the UC Open Access Policy had been enacted and in violation of the publisher's agreement with the authors when they gave their copyrights to the ASCE.<ref>{{cite web | title = ASCE Takedown Notices | website = Office of Scholarly Communication | publisher = University of California | url = http://osc.universityofcalifornia.edu/2014/03/asce-takedown-notices/ | accessdate = 3 April 2014}}</ref>
==== University of Colorado Boulder ==== In 2014 the Faculty Assembly of the University of Colorado Boulder approved the CU Boulder [http://scholar.colorado.edu/openaccess.html Open Access Policy] "in order to allow for broad dissemination of their research." They granted to The Regents of the University of Colorado "a nonexclusive, irrevocable, worldwide license to exercise any and all rights under copyright relating to their scholarly work, as long as the works are properly attributed to the authors and not used for commercial purposes"—and that the individual faculty would retain full ownership of the material. Authors at UC Boulder are expected to inform publishers about the University's policy and that they "have granted a pre-existing License."<ref>{{cite web|title=CU Boulder Open Access Policy|url=http://scholar.colorado.edu/openaccess.html|website=CU Scholar Institutional Repository|publisher=University of Colorado Boulder|accessdate=19 May 2015}}</ref> The digital repository, [http://scholar.colorado.edu/ CU Scholar], is maintained by the University Libraries and functions under a [http://scholar.colorado.edu/policies.html set of policies] derived from the Open Access Policy. Contributions from the CU Boulder community can include working papers and technical reports, published scholarly research articles, completed manuscripts, digital art or multimedia, conference papers and proceedings, theses and dissertations, Undergraduate Honors theses, journals published on campus, faculty course-related output primarily of scholarly interest, and data sets.<ref>{{cite web|title=Policies|url=http://scholar.colorado.edu/policies.html|website=CU Scholar Institutional Repository|publisher=University of Colorado Boulder}}</ref> The Chancellor's Executive Committee recently approved the new policy, following the lead of the Council of Deans and the Office of the Provost and Executive Vice Chancellor.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bolkan|first1=Joshua|title=CU Boulder Adopts Open Access|url=http://campustechnology.com/articles/2015/05/18/cu-boulder-adopts-open-access.aspx|website=Campus Technology|publisher=1105 Media Inc. Ed-Tech Group|accessdate=19 May 2015}}</ref>
==== University of Kansas ==== In 2005 the University of Kansas (KU) created [https://web.archive.org/web/20051101213846/https://kuscholarworks.ku.edu/dspace/ KU ScholarWorks], a digital repository for scholarly work created by KU faculty and staff. Faculty Senate President Lisa Wolf-Wendel, professor of education leadership and policy studies, approved a new policy, "[http://policy.ku.edu/governance/open-access-policy Open Access Policy for University of Kansas Scholarship]" on April 30, 2009, in order to provide the broadest possible access to the journal literature authored by KU faculty."<ref>{{cite web | title = Governance Policy: Open Access Policy for University of Kansas Scholarship | website = KU Policy Library | publisher = The University of Kansas | accessdate = 19 July 2014}}</ref> In June 2009, under a faculty-initiated policy approved by Chancellor Robert Hemenway, KU became the first U.S. public university to implement an open access policy.<ref><{{cite web | first = Rebecca | last = Smith | title = KU becomes first U.S. public university to pass an open access policy | website = KU News | publisher = The University of Kansas | url=http://archive.news.ku.edu/2009/june/26/openaccess.shtml | accessdate= 19 July 2014}}</ref> Unless a KU author sought a waiver, all articles must be submitted to [https://web.archive.org/web/20051101213846/https://kuscholarworks.ku.edu/dspace/ KU ScholarWorks]. "[http://openaccess.ku.edu/sites/openaccess.drupal.ku.edu/files/docs/OA_implement_process_Fac_Senate_endorsed2-11-2010.pdf Processes to Implement the KU Open Access Policy]" were endorsed by the Faculty Senate in February 2010. Theses and dissertations at the University of Kansas are also openly available, however in 2010 KU Graduate Studies established a policy that a student may request permission to embargo its publication for six months, one year or two years. Graduates earning the KU Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing or PhD in English (Literature and Creative Writing track) may request a permanent embargo.<ref>{{cite web | title = Graduate Studies Policy: Embargo Policy for Theses and Dissertations | website = KU Policy Library | publisher = The University of Kansas | url = http://policy.ku.edu/graduate-studies/embargo-policy | accessdate = 19 July 2014}}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === In the United Kingdom, the Higher Education Funding Council for England (HEFCE)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hefce.ac.uk/|title=Home - Higher Education Funding Council for England|last=England|first=Higher Education Funding Council for|website=www.hefce.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref> subsidized the JISC Academy Open Educational Resources Programme<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jisc.ac.uk/|title=Jisc|website=Jisc|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref>. JISC refers to a membership organization that provides digital solutions for United Kingdom education and research initiatives. The JISC/HE OER Programme (Phase 3 from October 2011 – October 2012)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://oro.open.ac.uk/52748/|title=JISC/HE Academy OER Programme: Phase 3 Synthesis and Evaluation Report|last=L.|first=McGill,|last2=I.|first2=Falconer,|date=2013-02-01|website=oro.open.ac.uk|access-date=2018-06-27|last3=A.|first3=Littlejohn,|last4=H.|first4=Beetham,}}</ref> was meant to build on sustainable procedure indicated in the first two phases eventually expanding in new directions that connect Open Educational Resources to other fields of work<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cronin|first=Catherine|date=2017-08-15|title=Openness and Praxis: Exploring the Use of Open Educational Practices in Higher Education|url=http://www.irrodl.org/index.php/irrodl/article/view/3096|journal=The International Review of Research in Open and Distributed Learning|language=en|volume=18|issue=5|issn=1492-3831}}</ref>. This third phase involved important stakeholders emphasizing fresh challenges and insights about the effect of OER and Open Educational Practice.
During this stage, the concept of electronic books and Massive Open Online Courses (MOOC) also emerged. MOOCs <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecompleteuniversityguide.co.uk/distance-learning/moocs-(massive-open-online-courses)/|title=MOOCs (Massive Open Online Courses)|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-gb}}</ref>offer courses at the University level without having to finish the whole programme. Many students get the chance to study premium courses online frequently at no cost. HEFCE made significant investments through the JISC and Academy from 2009 until 2012<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://openeducationalresources.pbworks.com/w/page/24838291/Open%20Educational%20Resources%20Programme|title=Open Educational Resources infoKit / Open Educational Resources Programme|website=openeducationalresources.pbworks.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref>. The objective was to encourage sharing and reusing of resources which provide benefits to higher education in the United Kingdom. More than 80 projects obtained funding during the UK OER Programme. Substantial investments were channelled towards the development of Open Educational Resources even as the benefits for stakeholders have not been explained properly. Sufficient evidence is needed to prove this point. One criticism is that many such programmes are not technically and educationally accessible to a worldwide audience<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jisc.ac.uk/full-guide/open-educational-resources|title=Open educational resources (OERs) {{!}} Jisc|website=Jisc|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref>.

Russell on "Open Standards in the Digital Age: History, Ideology, and Networks" (Cambridge University Press, 2014) | website = New Books in Technology: Discussions with Technologists about Their New Books | publisher = New Books Network | host = Jasmine McNealy | date = 27 March 2014 | time = | accessdate = 28 March 2014}} *{{cite web | title = Open Access | website = Center for Faculty Initiatives and Advancement, University of Kansas Libraries | publisher = The University of Kansas | url = https://openaccess.ku.edu/ | accessdate = 19 July 2014}}

Policy transfer
==Summary== Policy transfer is a process in which knowledge about policies, administrative arrangements, institutions and ideas in one political setting (past or present) is used in the development of policies, administrative arrangements, institutions and ideas in another political setting.<ref name="ejournal.narotama">{{cite journal | last1 = Dolowitz | first1 = D. | last2 = Marsh | first2 = D. | year = 2000 | title = Learning from abroad: The role of policy transfer in contemporary policy-making | url = http://ejournal.narotama.ac.id/files/0952-1895%252E00121.pdf | journal = Governance | volume = 13 | issue = 1| pages = 5–24 | doi=10.1111/0952-1895.00121}}</ref> Policy transfer has a long history with a variety of policies such as [[zero tolerance]] policing, [[welfare-to-work]] and [[Business Improvement District]]s moving between different [[nation states]].
==Academic research on policy transfer== Policy transfer has been the subject of considerable academic research, led primarily by [[political scientists]] since the late 1990s.<ref name="ueaeprints">{{cite journal | last1 = Benson | first1 = D. | last2 = Jordan | first2 = A. | year = 2011 | title = What have we learned from policy transfer research? Dolowitz and Marsh revisited | url = http://ueaeprints.uea.ac.uk/35123/1/PSR_Benson_and_Jordan_Policy_transfer_research_2011.pdf | journal = Political Studies Review | volume = 9 | issue = 3| pages = 366–378 | doi=10.1111/j.1478-9302.2011.00240.x}}</ref> Since the mid-2000s [[geographers]] have also played an important role in these debates (often use the term ''policy mobilities'' instead of policy transfer).<ref name="McCann">{{cite journal | last1 = McCann | first1 = E. | last2 = Ward | first2 = K. | year = 2012 | title = Policy assemblages, mobilities and mutations: Toward a multidisciplinary conversation | url = | journal = Political Studies Review | volume = 10 | issue = 3| pages = 325–332 | doi=10.1111/j.1478-9302.2012.00276.x}}</ref>
Since David Dolowitz and David Marsh's (2000) paper 'Learning from abroad: the role of policy transfer in contemporary policy-making', academic research has focused on the issues of who is involved in policy transfer, what is transferred, from and to where policy is transferred, the degrees of and constraints on transfer, and its success once transferred.<ref name="ejournal.narotama" /> More recently there have been attempts to explicate the role of two way communication, and particularly feedback from policy stakeholders for successful policy transfer,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Park|first=C. |author2=Wilding, M. |author3=Chung, C.|title=The importance of feedback: Policy transfer, translation and the role of communication|journal=Policy Studies|date=2014|volume=35|issue=4|pages=397–412 |doi=10.1080/01442872.2013.875155|url=http://usir.salford.ac.uk/31743/1/The_importance_of_feedback_Accepted.pdf }}</ref> along with efforts to acknowledge the "indigenization" of policies as they are modified and adapted to context.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Stone|first=D.|title=Transfer and Translation of Policy|journal=Policy Studies|date=2012|volume=33|issue=6|pages=483–499|doi=10.1080/01442872.2012.695933}}</ref> The debates in geography have focused on the technologies and methods through which policies and ideas circulate – such as study tours, [[Business conference|conference]]s and best practice guides – as well as looking at how and why the policies change form as they circulate.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cook | first1 = I. R. | last2 = Ward | first2 = K. | year = 2012 | title = Conferences, informational infrastructures and mobile policies: the process of getting Sweden 'BID ready | url = http://research.northumbria.ac.uk/urbanfutures/conferences | journal = European Urban and Regional Studies | volume = 19 | issue = 2| pages = 137–152 | doi=10.1177/0969776411420029}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://research.northumbria.ac.uk/urbanfutures Imagining Urban Futures: Policy transfer and urban policy mobilities research website]

{{citation style|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = Asia-Pacific Network for Global Change Research (APN) | image = Logo of the Asia-Pacific Network for Global Change Research.png | image_size = 200px | caption = | purpose = | tax_id = | registration_id = | founded_date = {{Start date|1996|03}} | founder = | dissolved = | location = Kobe, Japan | coordinates = {{Coord|34.698380|135.215418|display=inline,title}} | origins = | key_people = | area_served = Asia-Pacific region | products = | services = | focus = Global change research, capacity development | mission = To enable investigations of changes in the Earth’s life support systems and their implications for sustainable development in the Asia-Pacific region. | method = Project grants, meetings and workshops, training | revenue = | disbursed = | expenses = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = 22 countries | subsid = | owner = | motto = | former name = | homepage = {{URL|www.apn-gcr.org}} | footnotes = }}
The '''Asia-Pacific Network for Global Change Research ''' (APN) is an intergovernmental network that promotes policy-oriented research and capacity-building activities related to [[global change]] in the region.<ref>APN. “APN E-Lib | Proceedings of the 5th SPG Meeting (2000 Islamabad Pakistan).” Accessed August 12, 2013. http://www.apn-gcr.org/resources/items/show/1825#.UgiTRqwlGVg.</ref> APN receives financial contribution from the governments of the United States, Japan, Republic of Korea and New Zealand, with in-kind contribution from all it 22 member countries. The APN Secretariat is based in [[Kobe]], Japan, hosted by the [[Hyōgo Prefecture|Hyogo Prefectural Government]].<ref>APN. “APN Overview.” Accessed August 12, 2013. http://www.apn-gcr.org/apn-overview/.</ref>
== History == The history of APN dates back to the 1990 White House Conference on Science and Economics Research Related to Global Change, 17–18 April 1990, at which then US President [[George Bush Sr.|George Bush]] invited countries of the world to join the United States in creating regional networks for North-South scientific cooperation at the intergovernmental level to deal with global environmental change research.<ref>Bush, George. “George Bush: Remarks at the Opening Session of the White House Conference on Science and Economics Research Related to Global Change,” April 17, 1990. http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=18366.</ref> Later in 1992, President Bush and then Prime Minister of Japan [[Kiichi Miyazawa]] signed the 1992 US-Japan Global Partnership Agreement, which, among other things, reaffirmed and strengthened Japan-US commitment to global change research.<ref>USDS and MFA. “1992 Tokyo Declaration on the Japan-U.S. Global Partnership and Its Action Plan,” January 9, 1992. http://www.mac.doc.gov/japan-korea/market-opening/ta920109.htm.</ref>
Discussions along these lines ultimately resulted in the establishment of three global change research networks: ENRICH for Europe and Africa, APN for Asia and the Pacific, and [[Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research|IAI]] for the Americas.<ref>Fellous, J.-L. and M. Hœpffner. “Global Change Research Networks: The Example of MEDIAS.” Advances in Space Research 17 no. 8 (January 1996): 11–16. doi:10.1016/0273-1177(95)00654-W.</ref>
APN was formally launched in 1996 at its first intergovernmental meeting held at [[Chiang Mai]], Thailand. In 1997, a competitive process was in place, open to funding applications for scientific research projects relating to global environmental change.
== Membership == Starting from 12 countries in 1996, APN membership has grown to 22 as of April 2013. In addition to the 22 full members, institutions and individuals from a number of “approved countries” are eligible for APN funding.
=== APN member countries === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Country !! APN Subregion |- | Australia || Oceania and Pacific |- | Bangladesh || South Asia |- | Bhutan|| South Asia |- | Cambodia|| South East Asia |- | China|| Temperate East Asia |- | Fiji|| Oceania and Pacific |- | India|| South Asia |- | Indonesia|| South East Asia |- | Japan|| Temperate East Asia |- | Lao People’s Democratic Republic || South East Asia |- | Malaysia|| South East Asia |- | Mongolia|| Temperate East Asia |- | Nepal|| South Asia |- | New Zealand || Oceania and Pacific |- | Pakistan || South Asia |- | Philippines || South East Asia |- | Republic of Korea || Temperate East Asia |- | Russian Federation || Temperate East Asia |- | Sri Lanka || South Asia |- | Thailand || South East Asia |- | United States of America || Oceania and Pacific |- | Viet Nam || South East Asia |}

{{Orphan|date=January 2014}} '''Policy monitoring''' comes a range of activities describing and analyzing the development and implementation of policies, identifying potential gaps in the process, outlining areas for improvement, and holding policy implementers accountable for their activities.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hardee|first=Karen|author2=Laili Irani |author3=Ron MacInnis |author4=Matthew Hamilton |title=Linking Health Policy With Health Systems And Health Outcomes|journal=Washington DC: Futures Group, Health Policy Project|year=2012|url=http://www.healthpolicyproject.com/pubs/186_HealthPolicySystemOutcomesConceptualALDec.pdf}}</ref>
== Definition == Monitoring policy development and implementation is an integral component of the [[policy cycle]] and can be applied in sectors including agriculture, health, education, and finance. Policy monitoring can improve policy informatioation among stakeholders, and the use of evaluation techniques to provide feedback to reframe and revise policies.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wong|first=Cecilia|author2=Craig Watkins|title=Conceptualizing Spatial Planning Outcomes: Towards an Integrative Measurement Framework|journal=The Town Planning Review|year=2009|volume=80|issue=4/5|url=https://www.questia.com/library/1P3-1899476771/conceptualising-spatial-planning-outcomes-towards}}</ref> Waterman and Wood derived policy monitoring from [[agency theory]], describing a process where policymakers monitor the actions of their bureaucratic agents who implement and enforce policies. This monitoring allows policymakers to compensate for their agents’ greater knowledge of the policy process, and enables them to be well-informed decision makers. Thus policy monitoring allows policymakers and interested actors to systematically examine the process of creating a policy, implementing it, and evaluating its effects.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Waterman|first=Richard|author2=Dan Wood|title=Policy Monitoring and Policy Analysis|journal=Journal of Policy Analysis and Management|year=1993|doi=10.2307/3325346|volume=12|issue=4|pages=685–699|jstor=3325346}}</ref> Policy monitoring activities can be used to collect and analyze data related to the development and implementation of specific policies. It can also help link policies to specific outcomes and help identify and evaluate policy impacts. Policy impacts can include specific changes in behavior (e.g., increased number of people wearing seatbelts), finances (e.g., increased tax revenue), health status or epidemiology (e.g., reduced number of new HIV infections) or other social indicators (e.g., reduced crime rates, reduced levels of pollution). Data from policy monitoring can be used to support advocacy efforts and guide the development of new, timely, and relevant policies. Policy monitoring should also include the identification of operational policy barriers that can be addressed through policy and program reform, and findings can support improved implementation of existing policies.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hardee|first=Karen|author2=Laili Irani |author3=Ron MacInnis |author4=Matthew Hamilton |title=Linking Health Policy With Health Systems And Health Outcomes|journal=Washington DC: Futures Group, Health Policy Project|year=2012|url=http://www.healthpolicyproject.com/pubs/186_HealthPolicySystemOutcomesConceptualALDec.pdf}}</ref>
== Challenges == Numerous actors and stakeholders can influence the movement of policy from inception to implementation. Well-maintained documentation and review of all key stakeholders involved in a policy can help advocates for a given policy—such as military reform, water rights, or disability legislation—prepare to address different ideologies, capacities, or interests of key actors.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jones|first=Harry|title=A Guide to Monitoring and Evaluating Policy Influence|journal=Overseas Development Institute|date=February 2011|url=http://www.odi.org.uk/sites/odi.org.uk/files/odi-assets/publications-opinion-files/6453.pdf}}</ref> Limiting stakeholder analysis only to government and official policymakers may ignore major groups that can support policy development.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hardee|first=Karen|author2=Imelda Feranil |author3=Jill Boezwinkle |author4=Benjamin Clark Benjamin |title=The Policy Circle: A Framework For Analyzing the Components of Family Planning, Reproductive Health, Maternal Health, and HIV/AIDS Policies|journal=Washington DC: Futures Group, Policy Project|year=2004|url=http://www.policyproject.com/pubs/workingpapers/wps-11.pdf}}</ref> Policy monitoring coalitions should agree on what they are monitoring and be succinct in their recommendations to policymakers.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wong|first=Cecilia|author2=Craig Watkins|title=Conceptualizing Spatial Planning Outcomes: Towards an Integrative Measurement Framework|journal=The Town Planning Review|year=2009|volume=80|issue=4/5|url=https://www.questia.com/library/1P3-1899476771/conceptualising-spatial-planning-outcomes-towards}}</ref> Policy initiatives themselves are often controversial, and policy monitoring can be contentious because it shows how well policy implementers and enforcers are doing their jobs. Those conducting policy monitoring should be thorough in their data collection and unbiased in their presentation of facts.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wood|first=Dan|title=The Dynamics of Political Control of the Bureaucracy|journal=The American Political Science Review|year=1991|volume=85|issue=3|pages=801–828|jstor=1963851}}</ref> Robust trainings on policy monitoring work can help organizations be systematic and effective in their policy monitoring efforts.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jones|first=Harry|title=A Guide to Monitoring and Evaluating Policy Influence|journal=Overseas Development Institute|date=February 2011|url=http://www.odi.org.uk/sites/odi.org.uk/files/odi-assets/publications-opinion-files/6453.pdf}}</ref> == Existing Models and Frameworks for Policy and Advocacy Monitoring == === PEPFAR === The [[PEPFAR|United States President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief]] (PEPFAR)’s Monitoring Policy Reform tool outlines the progression of policy development related to HIV from problem identification to [[Monitoring and Evaluation|monitoring and evaluation]]. The tool supports a relatively simple and uniform monitoring process which can be applied to any policy area. This tool can guide policy monitoring efforts throughout the policy reform process.
PEPFAR’s six stages of the policy reform process:
:'''Stage 1''': Identify baseline policy issues by conducting situation assessment
: '''Stage 2''': Engagement of stakeholders in developing common policy agenda
: '''Stage 3''': Develop policy
: '''Stage 4''': Official government endorsement of policy
: '''Stage 5''': Implementation of policy
: '''Stage 6''': Evaluation of policy implementation (PEPFAR)
=== [[Food and Agriculture Organization]]<ref>{{cite journal|title=FAPDA|journal=Food and Agriculture Organization|year=2013|url=http://www.fao.org/economic/fapda/en/|accessdate=9 September 2013}}</ref> Working Cycle for Country Approach === The FAO’s Food and Agriculture Policy Decision Analysis (FAPDA) is a policy monitoring tool that provides a working cycle technique to identify policy problems and improve analysis of policy issues. By incorporating FAPDA outputs, such as a web-based tool, country policy review, and policy analysis report, policy dialogue can be more systematic and encompass different actors interested in FAPDA data.
The cycle includes: Phase 1: Preparatory Phase Phase 2: Focal Point Training Phase 3: Policy Identification Phase 4: Quality Control and Validation Phase 5: 1st Discussion Focus of Analysis Phase 6: Analysis Phase 7: 2nd Discussion on Findings (FAO)
=== World Health Organization === The World Health Organization has started to develop dedicated monitoring systems for policy interventions on the social determinants of health that improve health equity, such as social protection and gender equity policies.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2471/BLT.16.184622 |pmid=29147060 |pmc=5677605 |url=http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/95/11/16-184622/en/ |title=The need to monitor actions on the social determinants of health |journal=Bulletin of the World Health Organization |volume=95 |issue=11 |pages=784–787 |year=2017 |last1=Pega |first1=Frank |last2=Valentine |first2=Nicole |last3=Rasanathan |first3=Kumanan |last4=Hosseinpoor |first4=Ahmad Reza |last5=Neira |first5=Maria }}</ref>
=== Gender === Policy monitoring can be performed through different issue-driven lenses, such as gender sensitivity or gender equality. Gender-sensitive policy monitoring analyzes any gender aspects of a policy or policy issue, and considers the impact of the policy on both men and women, as well as its impact on gender relations. For example, a policy that is shown to have improved the welfare of a household may not necessarily affect all household members positively or equally, and may have even exacerbated gender inequity. Gender-sensitive policy monitoring can help advance gender equity and improve policy implementation. Civil society and other stakeholders can use policy monitoring techniques to systematically gather data on the gender aspects of policies and use these data to influence policymakers to favor gender-equitable health policies¬¬¬—these processes are essential to facilitating [[gender mainstreaming]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Mohga Kamal|title=Enhancing Gender Equity in Health Programmes: Monitoring and Evaluation|journal=Gender and Development|year=2001|volume=9|issue=2|pages=95–105|jstor=4030592}}</ref>
== Application == A 2012 study analyzed planned policy interventions across the 22 publicly accessible PEPFAR Partnership Frameworks to understand how the interventions are related to PEPFAR and country or regional priorities. The study found that “policy monitoring by donors, partner country governments, and civil society stakeholders can help measure whether policy interventions are occurring as planned in order to further HIV prevention, care, and treatment and health system goals and, if not, can point to needed changes."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Judice|first=Nicole|title=Monitoring HIV Policy Interventions in PEPFAR Partnership Frameworks|year=2012|volume=presented at Second Global Symposium on Health Systems Research in Beijing, China|url=http://www.healthpolicyproject.com/pubs/152_HSRPoster.pdf}}</ref>
